div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about July 12
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about July 12.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said July 2
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said July 16

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 7,966 tons, will leave Suez about July 4.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 6,636 tons, will leave Port Said about July 9.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £8.0.0 ; London £12.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE in connection with the oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturday at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, calling fornightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, and Constantinople. in alternate weeks to

The mail steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Monday at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG, weekly from ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 22 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 22 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID every fortnight for ALGIERS and LONDON or LIVERPOOL.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. ARRAGAN 6000 Tons will leave ALEXANDRIA about July 3 for Liverpool.
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave ALEXANDRIA about August 26 for DOVER.
S.S. ARRACAN 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Marseilles & Devonport.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL in 13 days.
The Saloon accommodation is amidships and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Lights and have all the latest improvements. For further information apply to the Company's Agents.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Cunard Line.
div.p: Royal Mail Steamers from Liverpool to New York and Boston every Saturday and Tuesday.

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
45 FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - MOTOR MEETS ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. - MANACER F. REINSPERCER. 31-8-9r

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LTL, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Friday for Assouan and Halfa.
Spechial combined rail and steamer Nile Tours at greatly reduced prices.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: SUMMER SERVICE FROM APRIL 13th UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.p: SERVICE MARITIME ROUMAIN
16 Res Sesoetria 16

Par suite de la quarantaine de 48 heures imposee par la Turqie sux provenance D'Egypte les paquebots poste due Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandrie chque quinzaine le Mercredi a 4 heures de lapres-midi. Au cas ou cette quarantaine serait reduite a 24 heures seulement les departs auront lie le Jeuti a 4 p.m.
FOR PARTICULARS APPLY TO THE AGENTS OF THE
OTTA STERZING, Opera Square, Cairo
WEN. N. MULLER & Co. Sescopirie-at., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service 22 Febr.; 7, 23 March ; 4, 23 April ; 8 May ; 8 June.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: Strictly family Hotel. Built in 1904 near the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
J. VOCLES, Propr Manager.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA.
The Fashionable Hotel of Alexandria.
RESTAURANT AND ANGLO-AMERICAN BAR.

div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
Hotel Dragomans in Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: There is no change in the weather conditions. The mornign opens nice and clear with a light N.N.W. breeze and a steady barometer

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: Council of Ministers.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will meet on Thursday under the presidency of Boutros Pasha Ghali.

div.head: Cadastre of Sudan.
div.p: The Government has granted the sum occasioned by the increase in staff for the forth-coming cadastral survey of the Sudan.

div.head: Fatal Scorpion Bite.
div.p: Scorpions appear to be particularly fatal to native children this year and a young girl succumbed to a bite of one of these creatures on Friday last.

div.head: Port Said Improvements.
div.p: A vernacular contemporary announces that the railway administration and Suez Canal Company have come to arrangement to prolong the railway to the port.

div.head: Rabies in Alexandria.
div.p: Cases of rabies having occurred in Alexandria City, the Municipality calls the attention of the public to the regulation that dogs must be led on the leash as well as carry the custom- registration plate.

div.head: Municipal Commision.
div.p: The meeting of the Municipal Commission of the 26th ult having been adjourned in consequence of the absence of a quorum, the Commission will meet on Wednesday next at 4 p.m. whatever number of members may be present.

div.head: Caribaidi Centenary.
div.p: The Italian colony at Alexandria will, celebrate the centenary of the birth of Garibaldi on Sunday next. A procession will march to tha Italian College and then to the Civil Cemetery where two memorial plaque will be unveiled in honour of patriot.

div.head: Extended Sick Leave.
div.p: In consequences of the large number of applications made for extension of leave on the plea of ill health, the Egyptian Government has decided to appoint doctors in the principal capitals of Europe to certify to the necessity of extended sick leave.

div.head: Messageries Maritimes.
div.p: Intending passengers by the Messageries Maritimes "Mail Boat of next Friday are requested by the Company to claim their tickets at once, as there are so many applications for berths that they are unable to reserve for those whose passage is not certain.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Friday’s bulletin reports 1 new case of plague at Alexandria and five recoveries ; l death at Bebo; 1 death at Assiout; 1 death at Mallawi.; 1 death at Deirout and one new case at Damanhour. Saturday’s bulletin on tha plague records 1 case and 2 deaths in hospital at Damanhour, and 1 recovery at Abou Tiz. The cases remaining under treatment were 20.

div.head: Purification of Cairo.
div.p: At the raid made on Thursday afternoon a number of houses in the Esbekieh quarter of Cairo the police discovered five French, three Belgian, three Italian, subjects and one British and one Greek subject, who are recognised souteneurs by profession. They will hence forth be subject to police superintendence. The police also descended on a number of young women perambulating Kamel-street and have handed them over to the authorities.

div.head: Agricultural Society.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has ceded to the Khedivial Agricultural Society 29 feddans of State lands at Guezireh which will be utilized by the Society for the extension of the grounds on which Agricultural shows are held. Eight feddans of this land were handed over to a delegate of the Society on Friday last and the rest will be made over in November. The Ministry of Finance has agreed to advance the Society L.E 50,000 for the purpose of purchasing manure for retail to small fanners, the amount will be deposited with the National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: Water Rates and the Poor.
div.p: Yesterday morning a meeting was held at the Alexandria employees’ Society’s headquarters to consider what steps should be taken to induce the Alexandria. Water Company to lower its rates for the poorer classes. Representatives of the chief Benevolent Societies of the city were present. It was decided in view of the urgency of the question to convene a plenary meeting of all Benevolent, Philanthropic and other Societes of Alexandria for Thursday next, when a decision will be arrived at All Societies,which-have not yet received an at invitation to attend may, we are requested to state, consider this intimation as a formal notice to attend the meeting on Thursday next, which will be held at 9 p.m at the offices of the Employees Society, Rue Mitwalli, opposite the Averoff Girl’s School.

div.head: An Interesting Entertainment..
div.p: On last Saturday evening a new cinemato-grafie entertainment was opened at Lifonti’s Concert Hall at Alexandria. It consists of a remarkable combination of’ the cinematograph and concert gramophone, so that the audience is enabled to enjoy a spectacle with words and music, a fashionable audience was present and thoroughly enjoyed themselves. One of the most noticeable records was Tamagno's death of Othello, which was splendidly rendered, In the other records the personality of the artist was in evidence, but as Tamagno had died before the cinematograph reached its present stage of perfection, a pathetic interest attached to the song owing to the absence of the picture. Some of the films were highly amusing and they were almost free from the flickering which is usually the case. The entertainment will be given every evening.

div.head: The Mediterranean Fleet
Saturday's Gymkhana
div.p: A gymkhana, in honor of the visit of the Mediterranean squadron of the British Fleet to Alexandria, was held on the Sporting Club grounds on Saturday afternoon. Excellent weather prevailed, and a fashionable attendance, among whom several prominent members of Alexandrian society were noticed, filled the stand and lawn. Looking across the course and grounds one could hot help admiring the brilliant and animated scene afforded by the white suits of the officers and men from the visiting ships, interspersed by the khaki uniforms of our soldiers, and set off to advantage by the green foliage and an oriental sun. During the afternoon the grounds were also visited by a number of cadets from the Austrian man-of war, which arrived on Saturday morning. Commencing at 2 p.m., tire preliminary ties of the tug of war, and various ship’s sports were held, but the program proper did not commence until4 p.m. the first event being tent pegging on horses Buch of the eight competitors was allowed three runs two points collating for a. hit, three for a. draw and four for a carry of twenty yards. In the first arid second runs two good carries were made, but in the third, only one carry and a draw were recorded. Mr. Leslie Reid the winner of this event showed good style, making. two carries in life first two runs and a draw on the third. Great fun was witnessed in the -next two events, the first a bareback race, on donkeys, riders to sit facing the tail of their steeds, and a tug of war on donkeys. Competitors were riot lacking and a big demand was made for donkeys: in fact, the demand was greater than the supply. Roars of laughter ware-evoked by the ludicrous efforts of mounting, and, this accomplished, it was some time before anything like a start could be made, owing to the proverbial stubbornness of their mounts, causing the indefatigable Mr. Preston no small amount of trouble in his endeavors to get them lined up. Bat after much coaxing, pulling, and pushing, the scrambling mass was dispatched, the riders apparently having great difficult)- in retaining their seats, as many, yards had not been covered ere several acrobatic exhibitions. were witnessed, and competitors were rolling In the dust Only about a third of the starters finished the course, the event being/won by Mr. Jabez. Similar contortions and much amusement was canned in the tug of war on donkeys, the latter, not being used to the game, instead of pulling, would insist upon., turning in the opposite direction. However, the victory- went to the "Queen’s" team. During the interval too semi-final and final) of the tag of war between teams from the ("Prince of Wales" and the' “Dublin Fusiliers," and the "Suffolk” seamen and “Suffolk” seamen, were pulled’. These were well matched teams and the amount of grit and enthusiasm displayed.by the individual competitors were admirable. The Dublin’s were beaten by the “Prince of Wales" team and the "Suffolk” stokers proved victorious over the seamen, leaving the final to the "Prince of Wales" and “Suffolk” stokers. Here too a good contest was witnessed, every, muscle being strained to gain the slightest advantage. The ‘Suffolk’s” made a good stand (but the “Prince of -Wales” men were too good 'for theta, the boners going to the latter team. Some fun was anticipated in the greased pig competition, but the spectators were disappointed, as no sooner was the pig out of the basket than the competitors simply fell upon the poor little brute in a heap, and nothing was seen for some minutes but a struggling mass of humanity, reminding one of a Rugby “scrum.” When victor did issue forth with his prize the pig more dead than alive, and the only wonder was more it was not pulled to pieces. What sport or amusement there was in this-we fail to see, as sorely anything approaching cruelty or the infliction of pain upon a dumb animal should be tabooed by Englishmen, as the same end could be served and quite as much fun derived from scrambling a haw. in the Lloyd Lindsay on homes, the competitors in teams of four had to ride from a distance of 200 yards over hurdles, two dismount and knock a row of bottle off a table with potatoes, remount and ride round the distance post a winning post The horses jumped in good style but their riders were a trifle weak in marksmanship and in one or two instances the bottles were some time in falling. Mr. Porter’s team shewed the best time and style, and this event went to them. Mr. Jabez profiting from his experience in winning toe previous donkey race, won the apple and bucket race, in which too competitors had to ride a donkey op to a line of buckets, dismount and take an apple out of the bucket with his teeth and*ride bock to winning poet For the concluding event, the hack scurry, thirteen starters went to the post, and a good- race resulted in a win for. Mr. Forbes. At intervals on the other ride of the course “Jack” was having a good time, and the Arab donkey boys doing a roaring trade, in short donkey rides at anything from sixpence a time.

An excellent selection of music was played during the afternoon by the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, under the conductorship of Bandmaster A. Fawcett, and altogether we think a most enjoyable- and successful after-noon was spent.

div.head: Naval Sports
div.p: While the gymkhana was going-on on the race course, athletic sports for the bluejackets were being held on the polo course.
An energetic committee had boon hurriedly got together and their efforts were rewarded by excellent entries for all the events.

At halftime tea was served for the visitors in tents and the five or six hundred who participated seemed to. appreciate the faro provided. Through the kindness of Major Downing and the energy of Mr. Nunn of the Army Canteen Dept. the tea went off without a hitch, while the numerous assistants should not be forgotten. The following are the results of the various events.
Boot race (37 entries).'—1st Hepton, H.M.8. “Lancaster”, 2nd Boyce, H.M.S. “Barham”, 3rd Joice, H.M.S. “Diana”.
. Relay Race-1st- H.M.8. “Queen". 2nd H.M.S.''Lancaster”. 3rd H.M8. “Venerable".
1 Sack Race (forty entries)-1st Greenwood, "Irresistible”, 2nd Kelman, “Diana”, 3rd Joiceand Addy, “Diana” and “Barham”.
" 150 Yards Race for Petty Officers.-*lst 'Wilson, “Barham”, 2nd Elison, “Suffolk", 3rd Saunders, “Queen”.
Steeplechase. —1st Russan “Venerable”,2nd Woodward, “Lancaster”, 3rd Rennie, "Queen”.
Wheelbarrow Race —1st Edwards and Joice, “Diana” and “Lancaster",. 2nd Taylor and' Pride “Irresistible”, 3rd Russan and Thacker, '‘Venerable”.

div.head: Governor's Garden Party
div.p: On Saturday afternoon at the Sporting Club, during the Gymkhana meeting, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, ’Governor of Alexandria, entertained the Admirals, Captains, and Officers of the Fleet, and a large number of guests at tea in a specially reserved enclosure. There were over 200 guests attending the “At Home” and the scene was a most gay one, while the fashionable costumes of too » many ladies were most attractive. The tables were most artistically decorated with pink roses and stephanotis. To give the names of those present would be to mention nearly every member of Alexandrian Society, and it suffices to say that the Diplomatic Corps, Consular Corps, and both the Egyptian and all European communities were largely represented. The Governor entertained his guests in a most lavish manner and received them with the great courtesy for which he is so distinguished. At 5.30 p.m., when oil the guests were seated at tea, the band of the Dublin Fusiliers, which had crossed over from the grand stand, played a choice selection

div.head: Tomorrow's Programme
div.p: Tomorrow’s a lunch will be given by the British colony to the midshipmen of the Fleet at Aboukir, and on their retain they will be entertained to tea by Mrs. Robert J. Moss, at Colline Moss, Ramleh. * For the trip To Aboukir special trams will leave Customs Gate No. 14 at 11-10 a.m. and are due back at the quay at 7.50 p.m.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
Tomorrow's Aquatic Carnival.
div.p: The following is the programme of the Aquatic Carnival to be held tomorrow (Tuesday) afternoon by the Alexandria Swimming Club in honor of toe visit of the Mediterranean Fleet to this port— -
420 Yards team race—Fleet v. Club. 7 aside, each member of the teams swimming 60 yards.
Tug of War—Team of 4 from each man-of-war.
Polo Match—Fleet "v. Club. 7 aside.
Walking the greasy pole in fancy costume.
Diving Competition.
Plunging Competition.
Obstacle Race.
All entries for these events are at the post
Refreshments will be served during the afternoon, and prizes will be awarded.

A steam launch will leave the Marina at .30 p.m. to convey members and. their friends to the swimming bath. Owing to the short notice of the arrival of the fleet the Committee regret that they hate been unable to make any arrangements for the accommodation of ladies at the carnival.

div.head: The Austrian Training Ship.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the members of the Austro-Hungarian Colony at Alexandria gave a garden party at Nouzha Gardena in honor visit of the training ship, “Kaiserin tooth,” to this port The Austro-Hungarian Const J, Mr. Gyorgyey, received the guests, who included the leading representatives European’s and native society. Among those present '''ro Dr. Wagner, the acting Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, Prince Louis Alexander of Battenberg and a number of officers of the Mediterranean Fleet, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, and the sub-Governor, the German and Italian Consuls, Dr. Schiess Pasha, Chata- way Bey. Miralai Hopkinscm Bey and many other distinguished personages. Altogether there were about five hundred persons present scene was a most fashionable and animated one. Dancing was indulged in on the lawn to the music of. the English military band and a sumptuous buffet was much appreciated by all present. The garden party lasted from 4.80 to 7.30 o'clock.

This morning 44 of the officers and cadets of the training ship left for an excursion to Cairo. They will return to Alexandria on Wednesday, and the “Kaiserin Elizabeth” will leave on Thursday for Rhodes and Melos.

div.head: Steamer Movements.
div.p: The S.S. “-Creole Prince” with passengers and a general cargo, left Malta on the 29th alto, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Wednesday, the 3rd inst
The Papayanni liner "Andalusian” sailed on Saturday for Liverpool with 2669 bales cotton.
The Papayanni liner "City of Khioe” arrival yesterday from Liverpool.

div.head: Presentation to Lieut. Franklin
Retirement from the E.A.
div.p: On the occasion of the appointment of Lieut Franklin, Director in Chief of Music in .the Egyptian Army, to be Director of the Royal Naval College of Music at Eastleigh, this popular musician was entertained at dinner, last night at Shepheard’s hotel, and presented with a gold watch as a souvenir of his in Egypt

Dr. Clark took the chair and in proposing the toast of the guest of the evening, said that they were all familiar with Kiplings poem, on "8ergeant what’s-his-name” who had wade the Egyptian into a fighting mail,. but Lieut Franklin had performed a more remark-, able feat—he had made him into a musician. It was a surprising thing for any stranger coming to a land like Egypt, where few of. the people Could even sign their own names to bar Egyptian bands playing., all sorts of selections of European music, ranging from the latest light opera to the “Tanhauser” Coverture—ahd this under native conductor* This was Lieut Pranldjn’s achievement but if they wished to. bee his work at its best they mast see himself conducting one of his favorite native bands, then they would see that he had indeed performed the miracle of making music' out of Nil! mud. All this referred to his professional services to the Egyptian Army. But the gathering at dinner did not represent the army, but only a few civilian friends still left at the end of the season ; and to them it would be even more interesting to recall Lieut Franklin's splendid services in the cause of charity. Some years ago ho composed and produced, in the cause of charity, his opera "Sesostris,” which they might -one day see in-print; and more recently they had not forgotten that memorable performance of 'The Pirates of Penzance” before the Duke of Connaught, which realized toe record sum of over £1fl0 in an Opera House which at foil Opera prices could, only hold £250, an occasion when one stall alone sold for £50, which is probably a record for the Whole world. Lieut. Franklin pulled this performance successfully through although Working with amateur talent which, with all respect to. those present could only be described as distinctly raw.

In conclusion - too chairman presented, the guest with a “Lord Cromer” chronometer, inscribed on one' side with, the Ibis and Crescent of Egypt, and on the other with the Globe and Scroll ‘Ter Mare, Per Terrain" of the Royal Marine*' while/on the dome was the subscription 'To Lieut. C. Franklin, from a few civilian friends who have appreciated his musical services in Egypt 1894-1907."

Lieut Franklin in reply made some most interesting remarks on the capacityof Egyptians for music. He said that as reference had been made to his professional work he must say that on*reason for the result obtained was the splendid material that ho had to work with. He had trained Lands in England, in Burma and else-where, but nowhere in the world, he asserted emphatically, had he found such apt pupils as the Sudanese. Music, he said, was in them. This statement, coming from such a high authority as Lieut Frank- klim must be very gratifying to the native regiments.

Lieut Franklin further spoke of the great consideration and kindness which he had received in his work from H.H. the Khedive, himself an excellent judge of music. As to the “Lord Cromer” chronometer he. would greatly prize a gift that bore the name of the great statesman whose departure had ceased so much regret, but he could not, promise to wear the souvenir on every occasion for it must regret precedence to the watch he most dearly prized which was. given him by his own sergeants. (Loud chews).

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The first dragoman of the foreign Embassies at Constantinople paid a visit to H.H. the Khedive to greet him in the name of the Ambassador.
Yesterday morning his Highness visited the British Ambassy and M. Gryparis, the Hellenic Ambassador who was for some time Diplomatic Agent and Consul General in Egypt.
On Friday the Khedive assisted at. the Salamlek reception at Yildiz and was invented to dinner by the Sultan .
His Highness will arrive at Vienna on the 14th inst. and will stay there for some days before he leaves for Paris and Kissingen.

div.head: Casino San Stefano
div.p: Le Casino San Stefeno dUivre'des cartes d'abonnement de sqison pour l'entito au Casino 4 raison de P.T. 200 pour une scule personne et de P.T. 350 pour famille. Ces cartes s’obtieoncnt au secretariat du -Casino.

div.head: Esbekih Gardens
div.p: The Band of the Kings Own Scottish Borderers will play the following programme of music to-morrow by kind permission of C.M. Stephenson and Officers.
March of the Peers—Iolanthe—Sullivan.
Selection—A Country Girl—Monokton.
Valse-La Gitana-Bucalossi.
Selection-The Casino Girl-Englander.
Patrol-Egyptian-Lane.
Two Step—Geogia Camp Meeting—Pryor.
Fantasia—Voyage In a Troopship-Millar. Intermesso-On the Rood to Moaeow-LIU.
Musical Joke-The Jolly Musicians-(By Roqwat)- [M
(Ragtl. March)—Bin* Boonata over tha Bard Kbadlrial Antham.
God save the King.

div.head: Cassa Di Sconto
Question of Liquidation
div.p: So tar negotiations for a friendly liquidation I’ve been favorable, and unless a hitch occurs suitable arrangements -ought to be concluded, but * great deal depends now the attitude of the board ofidirectora.
The following is a translation of the letter addressed to the board of directors ,by the delegate* of the Ottoman, Anglo-Egyptian and Deutsche-Orient banks and the Comptoir National d’Escompte

Gentlemen—. At your request and using as a basis the various situations placed at oar disposition, we have preceded to approximate evolution the total assets of the Casta and we herewith append the details of the “dechets” under the various headings-. Our investigation has necessarily been hasty, and we have not, it should be noted, been able to appreciate the regularities in regard to the mortgage properties. It must be understood that in oar valuation we have not considered the eventuality of a forced liquidation, but have considered, the case of the continuation, of the business- or, at any rate, of a friendly, gradual and methodical liquidation. We beg to state that this valuation has' been conducted conscientiously and in accordance with our experience of business in 'general without any responsibility on your part.
The following is the result of the valuation: Alexandria.
L.E. L.E.
Accounts current
Advances on shares 342,000…48,000
Cairo.
Accounts current
Advances on shares 394.000…58,000
Effects Discounted
Cairo and Alexandra 447,000…40,000
Total Dechet 234,000

div.head: Bourse and Banking Co., LTD
div.p: A correspondent writes After we have had the report of the accountants to the exact position of the affairs of the Bourse and Banking Company Limited, a committee of the shareholders should be appointed to confer with the members of the board of directors with a view to arriving at some feasible scheme. The present proposals are entirely ultra vires* told aa it is an English company registered under the Companies Act of 1900, it still be necessary to apply to the High Court to sanction the scheme. The shareholders who have sold or bought the shares have a right of action against their broker* if the latter agree to the present proposals.

div.head: Cotton Worm
div.p: We extract the following from the note of the Ministry of the Interior on the cotton worm during the week ended the 20th instant
The provinces of Assiout, Beni Souef Mink and Keneh' remained immune from the from.
In the Bebera 2612 feddans in 50 viHagen were infected'and 2635 cleared.
In the Dakahlieh 22^9 feddans in 71 villages were infected and 1847 -cleared.
In the Fayoum 20 hints only in 2 villages were infected and cleared.
In the Gharbieh 153 feddans in 17 villages were infected and 153 cleared.
In.the Ghiza 164 feddans in 5 villages wore infected and.44 cleared.
In the Menoufieh 275 in 19 villages were infected and 280 cleared, including 5 feddans infected during the preceding week,
Jn the Galioubieh 198 feddans in 67 villages were infected were cleared.
In the Sharkieh 370 feddans J* 11 villages were infected and cleared.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton Market
div.p: The “Manchester Guardian,” in its commercial notes remarks:

The strength of the cotton market-in Egypt is little short of remarkable in view, of the collapse in stock* since the great majority of Egyptian speculators are interested in both, and tremendous losses have been experienced the stock market. The speculative position in cotton i*‘however, a somewhat elusive one at present. Our Alexandria ’correspondent, writing on June 16, says that 'the fluctuations of the week just closed amount in the abstract to a rise of 3-32T. on the old crop and a fall of 3/16T. on the new July closing at 20} and November at ' 20, after touching 20} and 20 11/16 respectively during the week: It had been anticipated that 10,000 bales would be shipped during the week, but the actual shipments only totaled 8,600 bale* against 4,000 last year, and this disappointment undoubtedly checked the rise. As the difference between this and last year’s shipments now amounts to less than 10,000 bale* the disparity will soon be levelled if the present rate of exportation continues. Notwithstanding the semblance of activity which still sustains price* due among r causes to the report that a Liverpool syndicate had been formed to operate on the July disparity of price, it Is evident that America governs the market, and that there is no particular strength at the bottom of Egyptian speculation apart from this.”

div.head: PERSONAL and Social
div.p: Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Minister of the Interior returned to Cairo from Alexandria on Saturday when he had been to say goodbye to Sir Eldon Gorst and the Miniate*. The adviser will embark at Port Said to-day sod and be replaced daring his absence by M' Carter Wilson, Director of the Personnel and Accounts department.
Canon and Mrs. Algernon Ward are having Alexandria for England and sail by * P. and 0. steamer “Oceana" tomorrow.
The Rev. C. H. V. Gollmer, who resides at 6 ‘ Roe du Musee will be acting Chaplain of -St. Mark's Church.

Mr. Rugene Ampest has been appointed Chief of the Anthropometric Department and Joseph Bey Khlat promoted Deputy Director of the Security Division at the Ministry of the Interior. Mr. Eugtna Ampest is a pupil of Mr. Bertillon Chief of the Anthropometric service in Paris and has been specially engaged by the Egyptian Government to organize the service in Cairo.

We are sorry to learn that during Saturday's polo matches at the Khedivial Sport Club in Cairo Mr. Graham had a bad fall from his pony. It is hoped, however, that Mr. Graham, who is one of the Club’s leading polo players, will only be laid up for two or three days.

Dr. George C. Rodocanschi, of Maraeilles, married Miss Fanny Vlasto on the 22nd alto. The religious ceremony took place at the Greek, Church Moscow Road, London. The Rev. Constantine Pagonis, late of the Alexandria Patriarchate, officiated. A large number of friends attended, including the leading members of the Greek colonies of Paris and Marseilles.
M. de Suzoni, who has been appointed local French Vice-Consul at Cairo, in the place of M. J. M. Bronus Banchovine promoted Vice-Consul, will arrive shortly in Cairo to occupy his new post.
Ee-Seyyid Ali Merghani, C.M.G, expects to stay at Khartoum until the end of July and possibly until October, after which he returns to Kassala.
